summary: method begins with calculating the hospitalized severe acute respiratory illness (SARI) incidence for children 5 years old and persons 5 years old from population-based surveillance in one province. this base rate of SARI is then adjusted for each province based on the prevalence of risk factors and healthcare-seeking behavior. disease burden data are sparse in low and lower-middle income countries. local data on influenza disease incidence and case counts are useful for decision makers in these countries to assess public health importance of influenza. determining the amount of influenza-associated severe disease will likely have greater public health significance in low and lower-middle income countries. 5 years defined as a modification of the WHO definition of pneumonia SDH. data input steps are in white boxes and data output is in shaded boxes. we calculated the rate of hospitalized SARI from base province. the number of SARI patients admitted to the surveillance hospital for each year was divided by the age-specific hospital catchment populations. we added an adjustment for HIV prevalence using the same equation [21],[22],[23],[24],[25],[26]. we did not have data on HIV prevalence in children in Kenya. we calculated this prevalence using an algorithm which took into account the prevalence of HIV-infected mothers from antenatal clinics and the expected vertical transmission rate. the prevalence of household air pollution was calculated by applying the proportion of persons cooking with solid fuels to the proportion of persons living in rural and urban areas for each province. the rate of hospitalized SARI by province was calculated by applying the risk-factor adjustment described in Step 2a. percentage of hospitalized SARI associated with lower-middle income countries requires quantification of non-hospitalized cases. for persons 5 years old, the rates we found for influenza-associated SARI are similar to those presented for low and lower-middle income countries from the same region. reliable longitudinal administrative data is not available in most low and lower-middle income countries. a second methodology is to perform healthcare utilization surveys at each sentinel surveillance site to define the incidence of both hospitalized and non-hospitalized SARI. a more economical and perhaps more accurate approach would be to use data from one well-executed healthcare utilization survey. country-level influenza disease estimates will become increasingly important to ministries of health over the coming years. countries will need representative and ideally country-specific data to make decisions about treatment and preventive strategies, including targeted vaccination with currently available influenza vaccines.
